job_title: Administrative Support in Fort Collins, CO
pros: For the most part co-workers were really great, friendly, and helpful. Summitstone had grerat benefits as a single person, but it would be an issue for someone trying to provide insurance for other family members. People truly believed in providing the best services they could given the resources they had, making it a positive work environment.
cons: The executive management was extremely disconnected from the day-to-day work of their offices. Financially Summitstone is a sinking ship with executives pointing fingers and cutting budgets in area that greatly affected customer service. People in executive positions dropped left and right in the two years I was there including the CEO and CFO. Granted this is a non-profit company that depends on Medicaid money and grants, but it was largely mismanaged with billing not being done correctly and adding executive positions that were later on determined superfluous and cut when they realized how deep in the hole they were. HR was also one of the worst parts of the company. They are two woman the love to gossip and are on a constant power trip, they did things that would likely get them fired at other companies but they had been there so long management did nothing about it. They did do a company wide survey about HR and reported that the majority of employees reported that HR was unapproachable and most people did not feel comfortable reaching out to them.

job_title: Support Staff in Fort Collins, CO
pros: A small handful of staff were easy and fun to work with. As support staff I was able to make great connections with clients and genuinely feel like I was helping people.
cons:
Higher-ups are completely unapproachable. HR was an absolute nightmare; telling me after I was physically threatened by a fellow staff member that I needed to "get over it" and continue working closing shifts with him. My supervisor never made any attempts to interact with support staff as people and treated all of us like robots. Any time we would turn to her for help, we would be ignored or told to "deal with it". Any suggestions we made to make our day to day lives easier were met with "this is how we're doing it, I don't care what you think". We would be called disrespectful and insubordinate any time we disagreed with a supervisor. Therapists would constantly talk down to and mistreat the front desk staff, even going so far as to write insulting emails and gossip to other clinicians. 
In the year and a half that I worked here, I had my mental and physical health trampled on, my safety disregarded, my coworkers and myself were so mistreated that any time we were met with kindness and understanding it would bring us to tears. I have worked jobs that pushed me to the brink of suicide and this was still somehow worse.
